bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 29, 1905

div1.p: Gorgas seeks support for his yellow fever work in Panama.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 29, 1905
div1.opener:
C. S. O., No 8. W
ISTHMIAN CANAL COMMISSION
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER
ANCON, CANAL ZONE.
June 29, 1905.
Maj. J.R. Kean, U.S.A.,
Surgeon-General's Office, War Department,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Kean:-
div1.p:
Yours of June 14th received. The material arrived on the
22nd, that is, about two weeks from the time the cable left here. This has
taken the breath away from everybody, and we feel quite dazed yet.
Continue to ship as you have been.

It had been taking to another
under the Pub. Health Ser.

The Governor intends to give us our stores, but the details
of the change will not be made until the Auditor arrives. I have written
Phillips to see Turrill about the X rays apparatus.

Mrs. Gorgas arrived safely and is looking better than she has for
years.

Yellow fever is about as it was when you left, but our misfortunes
are increased by the addition of a case of plague which developed in one
of the long-shoremen living at LaBoca, June 20th; none since.

I try to keep the Governor cheerful by announcing every morning,
first, that the Zone is entirely free from Cholera, second, from Small-pox,
and then I go through with all the other infectious and contagious diseases,
and wind up by mentioning, in an off-hand manner, that we have four or five
cases of yellow fever and a case or two of plague. In this way I convey the
impression that he ought to be very thankful for the many evils which
he escapes.

It does not altogether work, but is the best I can do under the
circumstances.

I think that we will get along first rate, though I cannot announce,
as I usually do in my letters to you, that yellow fever is at present
stamped out. Tell the General that I am much obliged for his faith on
the subject. Of course I know that yellow fever and Gorgas cannot exist
at the same place. The thing is to make people at large believe in the
same way. I would be much obliged for any assistance the General can give
me in convincing the Secretary and others that Gorgas and Yellow fever
are incompatible.

Please remember me most cordially to Mrs. Kean, and believe me,
as ever,
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, W. C. Gorgas,
Chief Sanitary Officer.
